comments.text:
Ah. So this kind of test could be done with Paint, Word, or any other 
program that loads files locally. In this case, Chrome isn't so much a web 
browser as a local webpage loader. I wonder how fast Photoshop could load a 
local picture on a "MacBook Pro with Windows installed"? They wouldn't have 
to use any Internet connection there, either, if it introduces significant 
"variability".

Click "SHOW MORE" and skip to the end of the description to see what Google 
had to say on not using an Internet connection.﻿

You guys should try Google Chrome Canary for Windows 8.1.  Just go to 
Default Programs, set Canary as default, and watch awesomeness occupy the 
screen!
                         I
Advanced Steps V
1) Download from http://www.google.com/intl/en/chrome/browser/canary.html‎
2) Control Panel > Default Programs > Set your default programs > Google 
Chrome Canary > Set this program as default
3) Customize and control Google Chrome Canary (a.k.a. the three bars) > 
Relaunch Chrome in Windows 8 mode
4) Get a huge screen, maybe steal one from Times Square, and enjoy moving a 
bunch of Chrome windows around the screen!﻿

comments.text:
I realize you give the information and eventually, at the very bottom of 
your description, you all but admit that YOU, Google, have saved the pages 
to a local disk, but you don't actually say so in the video, do you, 
Google? You make it so easy for people to see the drama, but bury the very 
relevant details that would negate this fantasy performance to a very 
unlikely reality. For example, people aren't going to load Facebook from 
their hard drive or load and use such a page on its own.

So really, Google, you just misled everyone for the sake of promoting your 
browser. Fuck you. You're no better than any other advertiser. Really, 
you're worse than most because you're the one providing advertising to 
other companies on the Internet. Congratulations on your success, by the 
way. Under your influence and the spinelessness of those who let you get 
away with shit like this, I'm sure the so-called information superhighway 
will be just as commercialized and clogged up with bullshit as everything 
else in this fucking world. Oh! Too late!﻿
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+mapfilterfold I'm really suggesting that Google is trying to make 
themselves or their products look (much) better than they actually are.

I'm afraid I'm unfamiliar with any forks or the specific contributions made 
by Apple or Google, but I think the webkit thing sounds quite familiar. I 
think I heard about that in an open letter from Steve Jobs about why Adobe 
Flash wasn't on iPhones and his ideas on "open" which included the 
suggestion that Apple did webkit. I'm typing inside an extension or I'd 
look it up right now, not that I especially care, though :-]

I used to trust Google. I don't trust them now. I have my reasons, but they 
pretty much started with the first-gen chromebook I'm on right now. I used 
it for 3 years as my only computer, from October 2011 to present, but in 
November, I got a desktop computer from 2008 that has a Core 2 Duo 
processor almost 3 times the speed of the Atom processor in this chromebook.

I used to think Google was more exceptional and less selfish to the 
detriment of its customers, free or otherwise. The first thing I buy from 
Google and it's not "fast" at all. Not "fast" like the ads said. And when I 
look at an ad or demonstration like this, it burns me a little because it's 
another example of Google not being aboveboard. And I took a minute or two 
to shit on it because I fucking hate Google. I don't mean to waste your 
time, though.

I think I'm really just wasting my own ;-)
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
I should point out the extreme irony in your Apple vs Google analogy given 
that Apple was responsible for many of the most significant parts of 
Chrome. Recall that Apple forked webkit from kde first. Google was a later 
contributor, and this video was made long before the Blink fork.
comments.author: mapfilterfold

comments.text:
+Ryoco Wang Yeah, I don't think so. Unless you're suggesting the above 
speeds in the Google Chrome browser could be met via a particular ISP.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text: +Timothy J. Holloway​ You want to blame your ISP, not Google.
comments.author: Ryoco “Wn” Wang

comments.text:
+Ryoco Wang Google makes it very easy for watchers to assume page loading 
times are like the ones they'll get actually using the browser themselves, 
don't they? This is advertising, and Google is in control of the product 
and the advertising and any Internet connection being used, as they are a 
technology, Internet, and advertising company. If they don't say it in the 
video, it's less than aboveboard.

They could have done this other ways that would have seemed less impressive 
but more honest, but if they just put in the video that all pages were 
loaded from local files, that would have been honest enough.

The most disappointing part of this for me is that it would be impossible, 
using an Internet connection, to get the same quick results surfing the 
Internet. If Google is too afraid or sneaky to be clear on what's 
happening, they don't deserve to be treated as if they've been clear on 
what's happening.

This kind of "test" could be used for Paint, Word, or any other program 
that loads files locally. I think that would make a good parody of this 
video. Excuse me while I make a fresh comment to this video.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
+Timothy J. Holloway Dude don't get it wrong. The whole purpose of this 
video is about rendering web pages. Even though they saved the pages 
locally, the browser still had to render them every single time it 
refreshed. IT'S NOT CHEATING. NOT EVEN CLOSE.
comments.author: Ryoco “Wn” Wang

comments.author: Helge Neumann

comments.text:
+Dmazzone1 Yes, I use Gmail. I do, however, feel somewhat entitled to it 
when I'm allowing my information to be used the way Google does. Can't 
think of anything wrong with Gmail, though.

I think a new/different iPhone every year is just fine. It's right on. Nice 
and simple, and allows people to switch phones at a reasonable rate. 3 
years seems very long. This is Apple's main product which ties the others 
together.

I don't think it's necessary to buy the newest item, but that's no reason 
for Apple to stop releasing them. I only started liking Apple this much 
when I realized how difficult it was to find a great Windows laptop.... I 
want a portable computer and the PC laptops I've checked out all have 
crappy keyboards and touchpads, especially compared to Apple's.

I'm not sure what you're saying about developers, but I think Apple 
probably wants to play to its strengths, and the kind of gaming done on PCs 
isn't one of them. I think PC gamers want to heavily tweak and accessorize 
their platforms for a very custom experience. Apple hasn't arranged their 
business to work that way, and tempting gamers by offering the same games 
would complicate things all around, perhaps pissing gamers off.

You can run Windows on a Mac. So... those games can be run on a Mac, if the 
hardware's fast enough. The option is there, but not specifically on OS X 
itself.

I don't think your statement that Apple is catering to those who don't 
care/know about hardware is entirely accurate, but I've spent enough time 
in Apple Stores that I *really* can't argue. Both employees and customers 
seem oblivious to computers :-/

My point is that Apple is trying to be the absolute best and is constantly 
working toward being the best, playing to their strengths while constantly 
moving outwards from those strengths. At least it's through trying to be 
the best and connecting that quality to what people actually want, not some 
artificial dynamic like Microsoft had and has over the enterprise or 
upgrade cycles or networks or developers. An Apple laptop, I think, would 
give a much more lasting satisfaction than any PC laptop, and that's 
because it's not frustrating to use. Microsoft hasn't clued into that. Even 
Google and Chrome OS... or Android... haven't shown real signs of wanting 
to get it right.

Ever use Apple Maps on an iPhone? Beautiful. Totally different than the 
jittery Google Maps on a Galaxy S5, a real disappointment, especially 
considering how established the involved products and companies are.
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway

comments.text:
Perhaps apple should sell their hardware so it can be put into PCs. but 
that wont happen. then all apple has are fanboys. Apple should allow game 
developers to develop their games for macs, or whatever. If i can run all 
the games i can run on my PC on a mac, then i would buy one. Because lets 
be honest, Mac has the potential to be one of the best computers with the 
best software. But apple is catering to people that dont know/care about 
hardware.
comments.author: Cinimod

comments.text:
I'm not a fan of Bing, but there are other search engines. I can't claim a 
better than Google, but I'm just used to Google. Google has made sure 
they're just a little better than the competition, in general, but on 
search, they've probably made that margin as wide as they can.

Adsense is a relative mystery to me, but I'm assuming you mean that making 
money off the Internet is very much connected to Google's ad service, and 
in this way, Adsense makes the Internet and its content better.

Google is not doing anything terribly interesting or bright. They used to 
seem very interesting and bright, but I think they're now just fine with 
mediocrity. They're not experimenting, they're using their position to 
focus on things people want. That's safe and makes sense, but when they 
seem to purposely exploit users, they're no longer a glittering example of 
Internet innovation and progress. They're the bug-filled Microsoft of the 
Internet, too money-hungry, stupid, and lazy to do an excellent job, but 
plenty smart to make the most money all the live long day.

I think indie developers would be just fine, now. They don't need Google. 
They can find other ways. The Internet is developed enough, and yes that's 
to Google's credit, amongst others.

comments.text:
+Dmazzone1 OK, hold on. The technical specifications of PCs may be far more 
flexible and potentially impressive than Macs, but the useability of the 
hardware ~ that is, the quality of it in use ~ is, to me, far better on 
Macs. Perhaps it's possible to find and buy better mice and keyboards on 
PCs, but I haven't looked. Better keyboards and touchpads come built into 
Apple laptops.

Chromebooks suck. I'm with you. But the advertising for them suggested many 
things that Google didn't make good on. If they had made good on them, I'd 
be satisfied with my chromebook. I am not at all satisfied.

Not here to argue about Apple, but if Google was to Internet what Apple is 
to hardware, I wouldn't hate Google.

comments.author: Cinimod

comments.text:
+Dmazzone1 No. I don't see a better browser.

If Google really has so much to offer, why do they spin it? I think it's 
because Google has become ~ long ago, now ~ a company like any other, 
except that they're more connected to the Internet and they *used* to have 
a lot of goodwill to their name.

I've become more a fan of Apple, a company that, for the moment, seems very 
concerned with doing things right or as good as reasonably possible, which 
to me is perfect. I thought Google would attempt or was attempting the same 
with its products, but I think now that Google has fallen back on old 
techniques of using everyone as beta testers and only being a little better 
than the competition.

So, instead of inciting excitement in interested parties like me, they're 
the new Microsoft, content to release flawed or even purposely buggy 
software for the sake of using everyone as beta testers. Currently, the 
Offline function on chromebooks can't be turned off or it doesn't stop 
taking up local storage when disabled. This "bug" has been going on for at 
least a few months and ~ oh my goodness ~ what a coincidence that it gets 
people used to it *and* feeds Google lots of information on how it 
performs, at least on chromebooks.

I think Google is sleaze, but I do use their products. They're the Internet 
equivalent of the best PCs. Windows 8 and PCs basically suck compared to 
Apple hardware and software, and PCs could, theoretically, be much better 
if anyone actually cared enough to put in the appropriate effort on 
hardware and software, but they're too busy trying to make money the way 
they always have to do the job right or show some real initiative.

Here's the difference, to me: the vast majority of what Google does is 
software. And the vast majority of "bugs" they've shown that appear in the *user 
interface* or are otherwise obvious to users are *completely unnecessary*. 
And if it weren't for how much forcing features ~ like an Offline folder ~ 
on users benefited Google, it would be *easier* and *cheaper* for Google to 
take the relatively *tiny* time and effort to fix them.

I wish Google much ill. They've outlived their usefulness to me. If they 
were to just drift away, the world would be better off because indie 
developers would be more initiated and responsible... because there are so 
many of them competing.

And although Apple may not truly be perfect, it seems they've been pursuing 
some kind of perfection in order to impress their customers, and that's the 
best I see right now.

Apple should consider tweaking its browser to compete with Google's. If 
they made it a priority, Apple could come close enough that I'd really 
abandon Chrome, too. And find a different e-mail service.

I'll be wishing....
comments.author: Timothy J. Holloway
